MR. BLACK:
The next item is the proposed loan to the Aichi IrrigaÂ­ tion Public Corporation.
I would like first to calIon Mr. Quandt.  4
MR. QUANDT: The project submitted to the Executive Directors represents a noteworthy effort by Japan to respond to one of the country's most urgent needs, to increase her
domestic food production. With her territorial limitations, Japan must make every effort to exploit all land that offers itself for food proÂ­
duction of any kind, lest the burden of food imports on her balance of payments will continue to increase with the food demands of a growing population. Consequently, Japan's efÂ­ forts to increase her cultivated areas must include marginal
lands even at the expense of higher subsidies. The special significance of this project consists in the
fact that it represents a promising attempt to introduce a
novel type of land exploitation in Japan through the DrigaÂ­ tion of ridge land areas hitherto uncultivated or only cultiÂ­ vated to the extent of very limited natural possibilities. The successful completion and operation of the project, by demonstrating the technical and economic feasibility of the
irrigation of ridge land areas, should open the way for the exploitation in southern Japan of multiples of the area
covered by the project and thus represent the first step towards a new approach to a stlbstantial improvement of Japan's food supply. However, the expected direct benefits of the project
themselves are significant also, as they are expected to add 'I
5
food equivalent to about 100,000 tons of brown rice to the country's annual suppl1.es and also to improve considerably the standard of living of the agricultura.l population in the
Aichi area.
Subsidiary benefits, through the supply of much needed industrial and drinking 1'1ater to a numb,;?!, of municipalities and a noteworthy addition to the area IS poltler supply, wilJ.
8.1so contribute to increasing over-all productivity in the region.
The expectations for the success of the project appear
to be justified by the determination of the Japanese GovernÂ­ ment to assist the completion a.nd operation of the project, by the competence of the prospective borrower's management which has been assisted by experienced consultants in every sector of planning, execution, and future operations where thei
novelty of the venture called for it.
Last but not least, the traditional skill and zeal of the Japanese farmer will be genuine motive powers on the
road to success. MR. BLACK: Thank you, sir. Mr. Tolley.
MR. TOLLEY: Mr. Chairman, gentlemen: The economic proÂ­ gress in Japan during the past few years has been truly reÂ­ markable. This progress can be attributed to a number of
factors: the general prosperity in the world at large which  6
has provided a good market for J a,panese exports; the conserÂ­
vative financial policies on the part of the Japanese Government; but most of all, the credit must go to the JapanÂ­
ese people. It was their lndustriousness, skill, and pruÂ­ dence which originated and fostered the rapid advance. However, the advance has been so rapid that it is not
surprising that signs of strain have begun to appear in cerÂ­ tain sectors of the economy, and it has become clear that
some slackening in the pace is unavoidable. As indicated in the economic report, a number of steps have been taken to tighten credit and restrict imports. These measures are being supplemented by others which give further evidence of Japan's determination to control the situation. Government funds budgeted for lending to industry during the current fiscal year are to be reduced by 15 per cent. Nine leading commercial banks were requested to hold
their loans during July within the limit of repayments reÂ­
ceived during that month. The steel and electric power inÂ­ dustries, which have very large investment programs, have been asked to revie"T their programs with a view to stretchÂ­ ing them out over a longer period. Interest rat.es on savings and time deposits are to be increased to encourage savings.
Most of these measures will require some time to proÂ­ duce visible effects. The tightening of credit wan only beg~~ about three months ago. However, there are already  1
some indications that the measures are proving effective.
Preliminary information indicates a drop in imports in July.
il A number of important industries, such as textiles and autoÂ­ ii mobiles, have announced cuts in production, and wholesale II prices have begun to decline. II
Iii
HI It is, of course, much too soon to say that the corner has been turned. However, there is good reason to expect
that equilibrium will be restored in the near future. The newly appointed Finance Minister, Mr. Ichimada, is known for his conservative views on fiscal and monetary policies. DurÂ­ I
ing 1953 and 1954 he was one of the key figures in initiating and implementing the very tough but effective anti-inflationÂ­ ary policy which brought stability within a fairly short
period and laid the groundwork for the subsequent rapid progÂ­
ress in Japan. According to press reports, he is planning to follow a similar vigorous policy in the months ahead. He
has stated that the Government has no intention of modifying the present tight money policy and that further retrenchment
is planned in next year's budget.
These restrictive policies should end the inflationa~J
pressures and the balance of payments difficulties. Once this is accomplished, there are good prospects that Japan will make further substantial progress under stable financial
conditions.
MR. BLACK: Thank you.  8
Mr. Reid. MR. REID: Mr. Chairman and gentlemen: The primary purpose of this project is to irrigate 33,000 hectares or 83,000 acres, near Nagoya in southern Japan. The secondary objectives are to improve domestic and industrial water supplies for the area and to make a modest contribution to the power capacity of the region.
Now, this is by no means an orthodox irrigation project. Apart from being large and costly, it is unusually compliÂ­ cated and involves technical difficulties which are somewhat
unique. These have been very thoroughly studied by Japanese
and foreign technicians during the last three or four years,
and have been solved to the extent that we think the project should be supported.
NOW, we are well satisfied concerning engineering asÂ­ pects. Consultants acceptable to us have been employed for investigation and design and to supervise the construction.
We accept their findings and recommendations, and we expect they will do an equally good Job in the supervision.
We are also well satisfied concerning the competence of
the borrower, the Aichi Company, to undertake the project and operate it after completion. and the corporation has suffiÂ­ cient funds for these purposes. Agricultural aspects are less clear-cut. In the first
place, capital costs will be about $2,600 per hectare. Now, 'I
9
by way of comparison, this cost per hectare is $300 and $700
respectively more than the hectare costs for the irrigation
projects in Italy that we financed fairly recently.
In a country where land is used as intensively as in
Japan, it seems inevitable that costs of land development are
high. Otherwise, the land would have been developed years
ago. The Government proposes to meet these high costs by
subsidizing roughly 65 per cent of the over-all costs of the
development for agriculture included in the prOjected program.
This is the normal rate of subsidy for land development in
Japan. It is considerably below the rate of subsidy on other
irrigation projects we have financed. Given this rate of
subsidy, the operation of the project should be profitable.
The second agricultural feature is that operating the
system will be unusually complicated. The 16,000 hectares of
the 33,000 which is rolling, upland country will not only be
the first irrigation in Japan of this sort of sloping country,
but it will be the largest operation of that nature in the
world, and will present many difficult technical problems in
getting the right amount of water at the right time to
twenty or thirty thousand small farms, and particularly so since if too much water gets there at any time, it can
seriously scour out the hillsides.
NOW, the Japanese are well aware of these problems, and
consequently they are employing experienced irrigation  10
consultants to advise them, and they are also sending some I of their own technicians abroad to study overseas practice in so far as they can. We feel there may be initial diffiÂ­ culties in operatXn, but we are very confident that they will I be able to overcome them. Thirdly, since this again will be the first upland irriÂ­ gation in Japan, it is a situation where there is not as yet
sufficient evidence to determine agricultural crop yield and agricultural benefits to be really firmly assessed. The Japanese have made an exceptionally thorough study of all the evidence they have got, which includes the results from two experimental farms that they have established in the area, and the estimates are in line with that evidence. But what we cantt be sure of is Just what yields the Japanese farmers will be able to obtain, and how long it will take the
to get maximum yields. We are certain of one thing, however, and that is that Japanese farmers are among the most competent and diligent in the world, and they will spare no effort to get the best results on the resources they have been given. My remarks have pointed up the problems rather than the strong features of this proJect, and it is our firm belief that the competent Japanese technicians and farmers will be
able to overcome these problems. As Mr. Quandt pointed out, there is also wider  11
justification for this project because it is estimated there
are about 200,000 hectares of similar upland country in Japan, and hence this first attempt to develop it has an experimental nature. This doesnÂ·t mean that it is a hundredÂ­
million-dollar experiment that is going to succeed or fail in its own right. It means, rather, that if results are a little bit less than we anticipate, the project would still, we feel,
be worth while. On the other hand, if they are up to expectaÂ­
tions or exceed expectations, they will demonstrate the economic feasibility of developing a much greater area and making a much greater contribution to Japan's food supply.
MR. BLACK: Thank you, sir. Are there any questions?
Mr. Machado. MR. MACHADO: I read with a great deal of interest the report on this project, and I want to congratulate the staff
not only for the excellent presentation, but also for the excellent and to-the-point presentation at the meeting. I am ve~J much interested in the result of this experiÂ­ mental loan, if you want to call it that, because the success
of this type of irrigation in Japan may be the answer to the problems in some of the mountainous countries in Latin America like Haiti and Chile, and perhaps part of Bolivia_ and I am glad to see the Bank lend a hand in this loan. I am sure the loan will be a success, but the success obtained in Japan  12
will serve as a model that will enhance agriculture in the more underdeveloped countries of the world, particularly those I represent.
I would be very happy to support this loan, Mr. PresiÂ­ dent.
MR. BLACK: Thank you. Are there any other questions? Dr. Donner.
DR. DONNER: Mr. Chairman, in reading the economic reÂ­ port and the project report, I, too, was greatly impressed not only by the project but by the general features of the recovery in Japan, which Japan has been able to achieve.
She has had, during recent years, a growth rate of more than ~o per cent per annum, which, indeed, is a very high
rate of development.. Although, as the staff also potnts out, it can not be expected to continue in the future at that rate, the expected rate of growth of 4 to 5 per cent per
annum is neverth.s ss again remarkable.
All this has been achieved and is expected to take place on the basis of the response to what some people say
is orthodox monetary '901icy, se,::;:lng to it tha,t there does not take place any inflationa~; development, or that, as it shows up it can be tC.ken under control. 't'he JF.panese population, as is very neatly pointed out in the economic report, page 14, has reacted to that  13
responsible policy of its Government in the best "lay, th: 'v-ia:y one usually expects a government to react, namely, by
responding with a high rate of savings. Private savings as a per cent of disposable income was previously up to a rate of more than 12 per cent and is now in the neighborhood of 17 per cent, which is remarkable. And in order to put emphasis on the experiences of such a country as Japan, what can be achieved by -- quote "or_ thodox monetary and fiscal methods;' I add that the labor
productivity has risen again in a very unusual way, 8.9 per cent in a year. That is a rather unique figure. I thought it 1n order to stress this, since very often
there is a question in the minds of many people that what
could be achieved with rigi.d monetary or fiscal policies is doubted. The question is asked lii~1ether a certain degree 1t may be a bige;er degree: of lnflationary pollctes might not, in spite of all this advice, be better for a country, and
particularly an underdeveloped country.
I have, to conclude, two little questions which are more a matter of my Olm personal curiosity.
In the economic report on page 2 it is said -- no, excuse me; it is on page 14 that the Japanese Government has decided to cut income taxes by 100 billion yen since the tax revenues were so buoyant. But then it is added that they
were setting against this tax decrease of 100 billion yen a  14
tax increase of 32 billion.
Now, I assume that behind this measure of raising taxes
or decreasing taxes on the one hand, and raising taxes in
other fields, there must stand some specific idea. I would
be interested in hearing what this was.
Then, the second point is also a matter of pure curiÂ­ osity.
On page 4 of the technical report, paragraph 17, it is
said that Japan will send qualified technicians to the United
states and elsewhere to inform themselves about the technique
of irrigation \>lork.
Now, what we heard here and what the technical report
brings out is that the kind of irrigation work to be done in
Japan at the Aichi Project seems to be of very singular
character, of a kind quite different from the irrigation work
to be done in other places. So my curiosity makes me ask
in which respect for such a singular project can techniques
be learned other places?
MR. BLACK: Do you want to answer that, Mr. Reid?
MR. REID: Yes. The proposals for training these techÂ­
nicians will probably be in this country. They are intending to send at least six men over here, and their training will
be arranged through ICA and the Bureau of Soil Conservation.
We realize that there is not another project exactly of
this nature here or anywhere else, but what they intend to  15
study first is the operation and management, the actual
management, of irrigation operation in the mountain states where there are smaller schemes, but they have still got similar problems.
Then they will study technical aspects of applying water to soil, and soil conservation; and thirdly, the research behind this sort of irrigation.
But the basic trend they are looking for is in the operation and management of smaller-scale ones. DR. DONNER: Thank you.
MR. BLACK: Mr. Tolley.
MR. TOLLEY: On the question of the reduction in taxes, this reduction in general income taxes, I think this is on the whole a political decision by a new government which had recently come in. There had been pressures before to reduce taxes, and the new government felt that on the basis of reÂ­ cent experience, particularly in the last two or three years where revenues had been running substantially above estimates, this would be a good opportunity to put forth a reduction in income taxes.
As to the specific taxes, the main increase in taxes was on gasoline, and this was put forward to support another
measure which the government wanted to get through, namely,
the beginning of a highway development program. So that they
proposed this increase in gasoline taxes as support for their '.
16
other proposal to get through a highway expenditure program. DR. DONNER: I understand, then, that the revenue of the gasoline taxes would be applied to the financing of the highway project? MR. TOLLEY: That is correct. MR. BLACK: It's amazing how you find political considerÂ­ ations popping up allover the world. (Laughter)
Are there any other questions? Mr. Thurn. MR. THURN: Mr. Chairman, I would also like to offer my
congratulations to the staff on this very excellent economic report on the progress in Japan. We learned from this report that the real income in four years has risen 30 per cent in Japan, which is really a reÂ­ markable achievement. One naturally wonders how this has been brought about. Well, the report gives the answers in paragraphs 3, 19, 22,and 27. I think the economic order established in Japan and the incentives created there promise even greater achievements and more impressive results than that. I think it is a great
pleasure and privilege to be able to contribute to this good work by giving a loan of this type one's full and enthusiasti support. MR. BLACK: Thank you.
MR. THURN: Thank you.  17
MR. BLACK: Mr. Mejia.
MR. MEJIA-PALACIO: Mr. Chairman, I am also very greatly impressed by this project, this very important one, and I am going to support it.
As a matter of curiosity, I want to ask a question. It looks like the economic situation in Japan is like the
other countries, a little difficult, inflation, and deficits, and I am very glad that we are lending the money to them. They will take pleasure in it.
But I read an article that even if the Japanese people are very happy about the withdrawal of the American troops, they expect some economic complications, first, because it has been a source of foreign exchange, and second, because 80,000 Japanese who are working in the American Army are going
to be out of their jobs.
I don't know if the staff has considered the consequences of this withdrawal of the American troops. MR. BLACK: They certainly have.
Mr. Tolley, would you like to comment on that? MR. TOLLEY: Yes.
Of course, it is very difficult to project into the
future just what will happen to these so-called special United States expenditures in Japan. I think we did have a brief discussion in our report on the manner in which we handled it.  18
Briefly, we expect that these expenditures are bound to decline. We don't think they will disappear for a numberof
years, but we made what we believe to be a conservative assumption on the drop in these expenditures of roughly
150 million dollars below what they were in the past year.
Now, as to the current withdrawal which has been noted in the papers, there is no precise estimate as to what reÂ­ duction in expenditure that might bring about, although I have seen a figure which estimated it roughly at between 60 and 100 million dollars, roughly. And then I did see a furÂ­ ther statement that the Government, after reconsidering,
didn't feel that it would be as large as originally expected.
So, summing up, we feel that we have taken into account an ample possiblity for decline in these expenditures when we look to the future. MR. BLACK: Any other questions?
If there are no other questions, no further discussion, I would like to state that the First National City Bank in Ne
York has agreed to buy the first five maturities of this loan, amounting to $721,000.
So I would like to have a motion to adopt the draft
resolution, including this National City Bank participation. MR. MACHADO: I so move. MR. THURN: Second.
MR. BLACK: All in favor, say aye.  19
(Chorus of ayes.) Those opposed, no. (No response.)
The motion is carried. The loan in various currencies equivalent to $7 million to the Aichi Irrigation Public Corporation is approved.
MR. TUN: Mr. Chairman, in the absence of Mr. Watanabe..
I would like to thank the Executive Directors for approving the loan and the management and the staff for successfully concluding the negotiations. MR. BLACK: Thank you.
